channel.title: % in JAVA
channel.description:
I've seen it used in some formulas. What exactly does the % operator do when solving a formula?
Also, what does [code=java]double[/code] get used for? Is it for integers and decimal numbers?

item.title: % in JAVA
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

Thanks. It’s been a great help.

Read full topic

item.title: % in JAVA
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:8, topic:349149”][quote author=Lin link=topic=445520.msg3270931#msg3270931 date=1279191695]
More specifically, % is called the mod operator. If you didn’t understand Evil_'s description, it’s a more simple way of doing:

valueAFormatted = (valueA / valueB) * valueB;

[/quote]

As Graham said, you have that slightly wrong, it would be this:

valueAFormatted = valueA - ((valueA / valueB) * valueB);[/quote]Oh duh, I don’t know how I messed that up.

Read full topic

item.title: % in JAVA
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

c|p:

or you could just fucking tell him it’s the remainder of a/b

The first response said that, so there was no use going over it again.

Read full topic

item.title: % in JAVA
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:3, topic:349149”]More specifically, % is called the mod operator. If you didn’t understand Evil_'s description, it’s a more simple way of doing:

valueAFormatted = (valueA / valueB) * valueB;

As Graham said, you have that slightly wrong, it would be this:

valueAFormatted = valueA - ((valueA / valueB) * valueB);

Read full topic

item.title: % in JAVA
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:3, topic:349149”]More specifically, % is called the mod operator. If you didn’t understand Evil_'s description, it’s a more simple way of doing:

valueAFormatted = (valueA / valueB) * valueB;

It doesn’t do that :p.

int a = (7 / 3) * 3;
int b = 7 % 3;
System.out.println("a: " + a + " b: " + b);

Output:

a: 6 b: 1

Read full topic

item.title: % in JAVA
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:5, topic:349149”][quote author=Fat Cookies link=topic=445520.msg3271055#msg3271055 date=1279207040]
% is the modulo operator as Evil_ and Lin said. It’s basically the remainder.
double is a floating point number with double precision (64bits). It is a “decimal number” like a float.
[/quote]
Way to point out exactly what was already said in the thread.[/quote]
Way to miss out that nobody said what a double was.

Read full topic

double is a floating point number with double precision (64bits). It is a “decimal number” like a float.[/quote]

item.title: % in JAVA
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

% is the modulo operator as Evil_ and Lin said. It’s basically the remainder.
double is a floating point number with double precision (64bits). It is a “decimal number” like a float.

Read full topic

item.title: % in JAVA
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

More specifically, % is called the mod operator. If you didn’t understand Evil_'s description, it’s a more simple way of doing:

valueAFormatted = (valueA / valueB) * valueB;

item.title: % in JAVA
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

double would be a decimal;

and % (modulo) returns the remainder left when dividing… e.g.:

3 % 2 would be 1

Read full topic
